smell_analysis.justification: Every diagram page (overview, use case, activity, class/database, and state) contains visible model elements such as actors, use cases, classes/tables, or states; there is no diagram frame with an empty interior.

On the 'Väljakute funktsionaalne allsüsteem' use case diagram (page 2), each use case oval inside the 'Süsteem' boundary is connected by at least one association line to one or more actors (e.g., 'Registreeri väljak', 'Vaata aktiivseid väljakuid', 'Unusta väljak'); there is no use case without a direct actor association.

The use cases on the main use case diagram have distinct meanings: actions like 'Registreeri väljak', 'Aktiveeri väljak', 'Lõpeta väljak', 'Unusta väljak', and the various 'Vaata ... väljakuid' clearly describe different activities (registration, activation, termination, forgetting, and several different views), and no two use cases with the same actor obviously describe the same activity.

In the package/overview diagram 'Väljakute FASiga seotud pädevusalad ja registrid' (page 1), each package lists unique contained element names (e.g., within 'Klassifikaatorite register' there is only one 'Klassifikaator', alongside other uniquely named classifiers), and there are no multiple model elements with the same primary name in the same package.

In the transformed database diagrams for the various registers (pages 13-18), any repeated business fields such as person identifiers or category codes are linked via explicit foreign key connectors and FK stereotypes (e.g., 'isik_id', 'valjaku_kategooria_kood', 'valjaku_seisundi_liik_kood'), so there are no clear cases where the same data value is stored redundantly in multiple tables without a foreign key relationship. Identically named technical columns like IDs or names appear only in properly normalized FK/PK relationships.

Use case names on the 'Väljakute funktsionaalne allsüsteem' diagram consistently use a verb-first form such as 'Tuvasta kasutaja', 'Registreeri väljak', 'Muuda väljak', 'Aktiveeri väljak', 'Vaata kõiki väljakuid', and 'Unusta väljak'; there are no noun-only or inconsistent naming forms among the use cases.

In the 'Väljaku seisundidiagramm' state diagram (page 11), each state (Ootel, Aktiivne, Mitteaktiivne, Lõpetatud, Unustatud) has at least one incoming transition from either the initial node or from another state, as indicated by the arrows annotated with conditions and operation codes like '/OP1', '/OP2', '/OP3', '/OP4', and '/OP5'; therefore, no state is unreachable.

Both activity diagrams, 'Väljakute lõpetamise tegevusdiagramm' and 'Väljakute aktiveerimise tegevusdiagramm' (pages 3 and 4), show every action node (e.g., 'Vaata kõiki väljakuid, mida saab lõpetada', 'Otsi väljakut', 'Vali väljak', 'Lõpeta valitud väljak', 'Vaata kõiki väljakuid, mida saab aktiveerida', 'Kuva kõik ootel või mitteaktiivsed väljakud', 'Aktiveeri valitud väljak') with an incoming control flow from the initial node or from a previous action/decision, so there are no unreachable actions.

In the conceptual class diagrams (pages 5-10, 12), UML associations include multiplicity indicators at both ends such as '1', '0..*', or '0..1' on links between classes like 'Isik', 'Kasutajakonto', 'Riik', 'Valjak', and various classifier types; in the transformed database diagrams (pages 13-18), relationships are expressed as standard PK-FK connectors, which are exempt from this rule. No association line is drawn without any multiplicity or implied crow's-foot/PK-FK notation.

The 'Väljakute funktsionaalne allsüsteem' use case diagram (page 2) contains at least 11 use cases inside a single system boundary, including 'Tuvasta kasutaja', 'Registreeri väljak', 'Muuda väljak', 'Aktiveeri väljak', 'Muuda väljak mittaktiivseks', 'Lõpeta väljak', 'Unusta väljak', 'Vaata aktiivseid väljakuid', 'Vaata kõiki väljakuid', 'Vaata kõiki ootel või mitteaktiivseid väljakuid', and 'Vaata väljakute koondaruannet', which exceeds the threshold of 10 central elements on one diagram.

Across all class and database diagrams, no single class or table clearly has 6 or more distinct relationship lines on the same diagram; even central entities such as 'Isik', 'Valjak', and 'Klient' are connected to at most around five other elements, based on the visible association and FK connectors.

The spatial layout of related elements on each diagram is relatively compact: associated classes, states, use cases, and tables are placed at similar distances from each other, and there are no connectors that obviously span more than twice the average element spacing within their diagrams.

All use case names and activity actions start with active verbs: examples include 'Tuvasta kasutaja', 'Registreeri väljak', 'Muuda väljak', 'Aktiveeri väljak', 'Vaata kõiki väljakuid, mida saab lõpetada', 'Otsi väljakut', 'Vali väljak', 'Lõpeta valitud väljak', 'Kuva kõik ootel või mitteaktiivsed väljakud', and 'Aktiveeri valitud väljak'; there are no use cases or activity actions whose names fail to start with an active verb.

No use case, class, table, or attribute/column uses a name of length three characters or fewer; primary names such as 'Isik', 'Klient', 'Valjak', 'Riik', 'nimetus', 'isikukood', and the various use case names all exceed three characters. Short tokens like 'OP1' or 'OP5' appear only as part of transition labels, not as element names.

Entity class and database table names that represent singular domain objects (e.g., 'Isik', 'Klient', 'Valjak', 'Tootaja', 'Kasutajakonto', 'Valjaku_kategooria', 'Isiku_seisundi_liik') all start with uppercase letters and are grammatically singular; plural or lowercase names appear only in diagram titles or register/package labels such as 'Isikute register', which are not treated as individual entity classes/tables under this rule.

Attribute and column names across both conceptual and transformed diagrams consistently start with lowercase letters, for example 'e_meil', 'eesnimi', 'isikukood', 'reg_aeg', 'mahutavus', 'valjaku_kood', 'on_aktiivne', 'telefon_nr', and similar; there are no attribute or column names beginning with an uppercase letter.

Database tables representing domain entities in the transformed register diagrams use singular names such as 'Isik', 'Klient', 'Valjak', 'Tootaja', 'Valjaku_kategooria', and 'Valjaku_seisundi_liik'; plural forms appear only in higher-level register names like 'Isikute register' or 'Töötajate register', which per the interpretation rules are treated as register containers rather than individual tables.

Class, table, and attribute names do not use type-indicating prefixes such as 'tbl_', 'uc_', or 'strName'; the only prefixes present are key/constraint prefixes like 'PK_', 'FK_', and 'pfK_' (e.g., 'PK_Isik', 'FK_Valjak_Valjaku_seisundi_liik'), which are explicitly allowed exceptions and apply to constraints rather than to the primary names of classes/tables/attributes themselves.
